p: Models were estimated for each pathogen in WinBUGS 1.4.3 ( http://www.mrc-bsu.cam.ac.uk/software/bugs/) using weakly informative normal priors for all fixed and random effects. The standard deviation for each of the group-level random effects was defined using a wide uniform hyper-prior (i.e. Uniform(1,100)). Model convergence was confirmed by visual assessment of MCMC chains. Inference was based on 3 chains that were allowed to run for at least 70,000 iterations after a burn-in of at least 30,000 with a thinning interval of at least 10. We derived the median and 2.5 th and 97.5 th percentiles from posterior distributions of each parameter for point estimates and 95% credibility intervals, respectively. All data manipulation was performed in R statistical environment (R version 3.1.1, http://cran.r-project.org/) with logistic regression models estimated via the R2WinBUGs package [ 42]. Estimation was performed within a Bayesian framework based on MCMC to reduce bias in the estimates for random effect parameters [ 43], and for ease of estimation of the associated uncertainty for GCE.
